By Liouville's theorem, this theorem states that if a constant is arithmetically independent of the primes then it cannot be algebraic. And since $$\sin(\pi x),$$ the Euler Mascheroni constant is arithmetically independent of all primes, it follows that that the constant cannot be algebraic. This is because if it were algebraic then the sine function would have a priori period of an odd number of digits (and hence an odd number of zeroes) at some point, which is impossible. Also, the arithmetic properties of the constant are as expected: length of a period is unchanged under addition of an integer, and is reversed under negation. That is why the constant is irrational.
